title: Kelly Miller
text:
Kelly Miller (1863-1939) was the first African American graduate student in mathematics at Johns Hopkins University. Later, as dean of Howard University (1903-1935) and founder of the Negro Sanhedrin (1924), Miller served as a crucial network connector between W.E.B. Du Bois and other Black intellectual leaders.


Mathematics Scholarship:

Studied under mathematician Simon Newcomb at Johns Hopkins
First Black student to complete graduate-level mathematics coursework in the U.S.
Applied mathematical reasoning to social analysis in early sociological work

Negro Sanhedrin (1924):

Convened 200+ Black leaders in Chicago to coordinate civil rights strategy
Positioned between Du Bois’ radicalism (NAACP) and Garvey’s nationalism
Created formal network structure for Black leadership coordination




Miller’s brokerage position linked:

W.E.B. Du Bois (Harvard PhD, The Souls of Black Folk, NAACP)
Booker T. Washington (Tuskegee, economic self-help)
Carter G. Woodson (Association for the Study of Negro Life)
Howard University faculty and HBCU presidents

Key documented ties:

Published Du Bois’ early sociological work in Howard University Record
Mediated between Niagara Movement and Tuskegee Machine
Corresponded with mathematicians and statisticians analyzing racial data





Library of Congress: Miller Papers (correspondence with Du Bois, Washington)
Howard University Archives: Dean records, Sanhedrin proceedings
Moorland-Spingarn Research Center: Negro Sanhedrin delegate lists
Johns Hopkins University: Early graduate student records

title: Archival Collections
text:
Collections organized by institution, with notes on network contributions.



Moorland-Spingarn Research Center
Kelly Miller Papers, Negro Sanhedrin records. Primary source for brokerage centrality - documents Miller’s connections between Du Bois, Washington, and HBCU presidents.
University Archives
Faculty lists, dean records (Miller 1903-1939). Institutional overlap edges between Haynes, Miller, and modern faculty.





University Archives Photograph Collection
Euphemia Haynes photos, dissertation records. Visual + biographical metadata for Haynes network position.
PhD Dissertation Collection
Haynes’ 1943 Symmetric Correspondences. Earliest node attributes for first Black woman math PhD.





Manuscript Division - Kelly Miller Papers
Correspondence with Du Bois, Washington. Highest-quality correspondence edges - direct evidence of intellectual networks.





DC Public Schools Historical Collection
Haynes’ teaching records (Miner Teachers College). Classroom mentorship ties - student advising networks.

title: Overview
text:
The Connections Project
Hello friends! Welcome to the Connections Project where we explore how archival records \(\times\) network analysis expands our knowledge of the lives and work of Black mathematicians.

title: The Haynes Project
text:
“The Haynes Project: Exhibiting the Historical Significance of the Philosophical Views of American Mathematicians” is a three-year funded initiative creating a comprehensive digital repository of Dr. Euphemia Lofton Haynes (1890-1980) — the first African American woman to earn a PhD in mathematics (Catholic University, 1943). Led by John Stigall (Director, Howard University) and co-director Nathan Alexander (Howard University), this flagship project anchors The Connections Project.


Network Analysis Focus

Haynes was central node connecting HBCU faculty, DC educators, and civil rights mathematicians
Institutional ties (Smith College, Chicago, Catholic U, Miner Teachers College)
Professional relationships during school desegregation era

Philosophical Significance
The project recovers Haynes’ philosophical views on mathematics education, school integration, and Black intellectual networks—lost contributions now digitized for public access and scholarly analysis.
